Name: Temple of Sobek
Description: The temple of Sobek was discovered in AD 1912 at Theadelphia in Faiyum. In AD 1913, the temple was moved to Alexandria and rebuilt in the museum's garden. The temple is preceded by two lions and it consists of three gateways leading to the shrine of the god Pnepheros. A Greek dedication text on the first pylon, or gateway, is dated 137 BC. The shrine is divided into three parts, which still show remains of decorations in the Egyptian style. A frieze, or decorative band, depicts serpents carrying a solar disk. The middle compartment of the shrine has the stretcher for transporting the mummified sacred crocodile.On top of its door is a scene portraying the River Nile of Upper Egypt and the River Nile of Lower Egypt with the sign of unity depicted between them. On both sides are mummified crocodiles.
